content.query:
select * 
  from users
join orders
on users.id = orders.id
where {{!input17.value}} or lower(users.name) like '%{{input17.value.toLowerCase()}}%'

props.value:
### Useful data
**selectedCell**: an object contains 3 attribute:  

1. index: the index of the row containing the cell in the data source is not affected by filtering, sorting, or other operations.

  2. columnName: the column name of the cell's column. This is the column name provided by the data source, and changing the displayed column name only through the inspect panel will not affect this value.

3. value: the original value returned by the data source

4. mappedValue: when a mapped value has been set, the mapped value.

### How to use it
1. Use `table1.selectedCell.value` to get the value
2. Use `table1.dataSourceJS[table5.selectedCell.index].id` to get the data on the same row (the example statement is get id) .

To use server-side pagination, you need to first turn on the server-side pagination switch from the inspect panel on the right.
We support three types of server-side pagination: `limit-offset based`, `cursor-based`, and `GraphQL Relay cursor-based`.

### Limit offset based

#### Required fields on the inspect panel

**Total row count**: to set the total rows the table will display. It is used to count how many pages and whether there is the next page.
You can set it via a query like `select count(*) from t1`. If the data source of the table has some filters like `where t1.dt>="2023-01-01"`, the query used in total row count should be the same like `select count(*) from t1 where t1.dt>="2023-01-01`.  
**PageSize**: to set how many rows in 1 page.

#### Useful data

**pageSize**: a number used to set limit in query  
  
**pageIndex**: current page index. a number start from 0. For example, when the page number is 2, the index will be 1. Use {\{table1.pageIndex*table1.pageSize}} to set offset or skip in query.

#### How to use it

##### SQL

```
select *
from t1
limit {\{table1.pageSize}}
offset {\{table1.pageIndex*table1.pageSize}}
```
The inspect panel:  
1. Enable serverside pagination
2. Change the mode to limit-offset based
3. Total rows(you can alse use count(*) in SQL statement to count the total rows): {\{list_all_products.data.products.length}}  
4. PageSize: set a number such as {\{10}}

##### API

***This syntax may vary based on different APIs.***

```
?limit={\{table2.pageSize}}&skip={\{table2.pageIndex*table2.pageSize}}
```

### Cursor based / GraphQL Relay cursor

#### Required fields on the inspect panel

**Total row count**: to set the total rows the table will display. For example, `{\{graphql1.data.totalCount}}`
**Previous cursor**: to set the page start cursor. For example, `{\{graphql1.data.pageInfo.startCursor}}`
**Next cursor**: to set the page end cursor. For example, `{\{graphql1.data.pageInfo.endCursor}}`
**PageSize**: to set how many rows in 1 page.

#### Useful data

**pageSize**: used to set the numIssues
**beforeCursor**: used to set the beforeCursor
**nextCursor**: used to set the nextCursor

#### How to use it

The following is a GraphQL demo.
**Query**:

```
query ($repoOwner: String!, $repoName: String!, $first: Int, $last: Int, $beforeCursor: String, $afterCursor: String) {
   repository(owner: $repoOwner, name: $repoName) {
      issues(first: $first, last: $last,       before: $beforeCursor, after: $afterCursor) {
         pageInfo {
            hasNextPage
            hasPreviousPage
            endCursor
            startCursor
         }
         totalCount
         edges {
            cursor
            node {
               title
               number
               url
            }
         }
      }
   }
}
```

**Variables**:

  ---
| key | value |
| :--- | :--- |
| repoOwner | tensorflow |
| repoName | tensorflow |
| numIssues | {\{table1.pageSize}} |
| beforeCursor | {\{table1.beforeCursor}} |
| nextCursor | {\{table1.nextCursor}} |
| first | {\{table1.nextCursor ? table1.pageSize: table1.beforeCursor && table1.nextCursor ? null : table1.pageSize}} |
| last | {\{table1.beforeCursor ? table.pageSize: null}} |
The following is a limit offset based demo

props.value: filter data: price>=x and price<=y and brand not contain z
filter data: title contains xxx or brand contains xxx

**There are two ways to set filters.**  
 
  1. Configure the table in the inspect panel, find the filter switch under the toolbar category, and turn it on so that users can directly set filters on the table.

2. Add event handlers for other components to enable them to control the table and set filters on the table.

### Set filters
It is a method used to control a table component and set filters. There are 2 fields in this method. 
  **filters**: It is an array of filter objects. The filter object contains 3 attributes:   
1. id--the column id,   
  2. value--the target value, 
  
  3. filterFn: the filter functions such as equalTo.   

  For example, price>=10, the filter object will be 
```js
{
   "id":"price", 
   "value":10, 
   "filterFn":"notLessThan"
}
```
  
**filter mode**: When you add multiple filters in the filter array above, use this field to set these filters are set with an AND or an OR relationship
# Click button on table to trigger event handler

selectedRow.description: An apple mobile which is nothing like apple
selectedRow.title: iPhone 9

selectedRow.description: Huawei‚Äôs re-badged P30 Pro New Edition was officially unveiled yesterday in Germany and now the device has made its way to the UK.
selectedRow.title: Huawei P30

props.value:
### What is the event handler
An event handler is a function that listens for a specified event and triggers the desired functionality of the target task when that event occurs. We support listening to different events in various components and actions.  
 
  For example, if you want to trigger a query when a button is clicked, you would need to use an event handler to listen for the button's click event and trigger the query accordingly.  
  This article mainly introduces the events that the table component supports listening to and their usage.
### How to add an event handler

### Usage
This is very useful when you use server-side pagination. You can use tableX.sort.sortKey to set the order by column and use tableX.sort.sortOrder to set the order direction. 

### Useful data
**sort**. an object which contains 2 atrributes, 
1. sortKey: which column is sorted
2. sortOrder: ascend or descend
### How to use it
#### API
***This syntax may vary based on different APIs.***
```
?sort={\{table1.sort.sortKey}}&order={\{table1.sort.sortOrder=="ascend"?"asc":"desc"}}
```

### Usage
This is very useful when you use server-side pagination. You can use tableX.pageIndex * tableX.pageSize(or tableX.paginationOffset) to set the offset value

### Useful data
**pageIndex**. a number starting from 0.   
  **pageSize**. the page size you set on the inspect panel.  
  **paginationOffset**: Used to set the offset or skip in query. It is the same as {\{table1.pageIndex*table1.pageSize}}

### How to use it
#### SQL
```
select * from 
t1
offset {\{table8.pageSize*table8.pageIndex}}
limit {\{table8.pageSize}}
```

#### API
***This syntax may vary based on different APIs.***
```
?limit={\{table2.pageSize}}&skip={\{table2.pageIndex*table2.pageSize}}
```

### Usage
This is very useful when you use server-side pagination. 

### Useful data
**filters**. an array of filter object. The filter object contains 3 atrributes,  
 1. id--the column id,   
  2. value--the target value, 
  
  3. filterFn: the filter functions such as equalTo.   

  For example, price>=10, the filter object will be 
```
{
   "id":"price", 
   "value":10, 
   "filterFn":"notLessThan"
}
```
### How to use it
You can use the data in filters to set your query. 
#### SQL

```
select * from 
t1
where {\{table1.filters[0].id}}='{table1.filters[0].value}'
offset {\{table1.pageSize*table1.pageIndex}}
limit {\{table1.pageSize}}
```

and the total rows should be
```
select count(*) from 
t1
where {\{table1.filters[0].id}}='{table1.filters[0].value}'
```
and you can also calculate the total pages after filtering: {\{table1.totalRowCount/table1.pageSize}}

### Usage
When you want to trigger certain actions when the selected rows change, you can use this event handler. For example, when a row is selected, you can trigger a new query based on its ID.

### Useful data
**selectedRow**. an array of 
row data objects.   
  When the table allows selecting multiple row, you can use table1.selectedRow to get the data of the selected rows.  
  When the table only allows selecting a single row, you can use table1.selectedRow[0] to get the data of the selected row and use table1.selectedRow[0].columnName to get any column data in the selected row.   
  **selectRowIndex**: an array of all selectedRow indexes. 
### How to use it
For example, to trigger a query where id = selectedRow[0].id
#### SQL
```
select * from 
t1
where id = '{\{table1.selectedRow[0].id}}'
```

### Usage
Used to trigger certain actions when the row is clicked.   
  When enabled multiple rows selection, it will be different from row select change.   
  When disabled multiple rows selection, it will be same with row select change

### Usage
When the data in your database may be updated, the refresh event will be useful. 

  ### How to use it
For example, the data source of the table is {\{list_all_products.data.products}} (`list_all_product` is the query). You can set the event handler as follows: 1. set the event to Refresh 2. set the action to trigger action 3. change the action to `list_all_product`  
And we will re-run `list_all_product` when trigger the refresh(You can try to trigger it via clicking the refresh icon on the tableüëá)

### Usage
Used to trigger certain actions when the cell is clicked and selected.   

  To use it, you have to turn on the switch on the inspect panel

### Useful data
**selectedCell**: an object contains 3 attribute:  

1. index: the index of the row containing the cell in the data source is not affected by filtering, sorting, or other operations.

  2. columnName: the column name of the cell's column. This is the column name provided by the data source, and changing the displayed column name only through the inspect panel will not affect this value.

3. value: the original value returned by the data source

4. mappedValue: when a mapped value has been set, the mapped value.

### How to use it
1. Use `table1.selectedCell.value` to get the value
2. Use `table1.dataSourceJS[table5.selectedCell.index].id` to get the data on the same row (the example statement is get id) .

props.value:
### Usage
**currentRow** is very helpful when you want to configure each cell in a column based on some data that changes with the row it belongs to.   
### How to use it
Most of the properties related to the columns can be configured using currentRow. For example,   
1. If you want the data displayed in column1 to be the original data in column1 multiplied by 10, you can use currentRow.column1*10.  

2. When you want the color of each cell in column1 to be determined by its own value, red for >=500 and green for <500, you can use currentRow.column1>=500? "red": "green"

### Tips
You can use the currentRow only on the table inspect panel. And you do not need to use tableX. to call currentRow, as this will result in an error (‚ùå table1.currentRow.titleÔºõ‚úÖ currentRow.title)
# Control table via other components or actions

### We support the following methods

1. Set filter: you can check it in [Search by filter](https://builder.illacloud.com/illacloud_demo/deploy/app/ILAex4p1C7Ga/page1/View%207)
2. Clear filter: this method will clear the filters set on the table
3. Select row: use a number to set the row index to select. The index starts from 0
4. Clear selection: clear the selected row
5. Select page: use a number to set the page index to select. The index starts from 0
6. Set sort: use **column name** and **direction(ascend, descend)** to set sort
